central_thesis: The text presents a complete and practical system of ceremonial magic, focusing on the invocation of planetary spirits, exemplified by Turiel as a messenger of Jupiter, to obtain wisdom, knowledge, and assistance in magical operations, as rediscovered and re-contextualized by Marius Malchus in 1954.

structure_content.summary: Marius Malchus recounts his acquisition of the grimoire in Las Palmas in 1927, noting its original 1518 Latin manuscript and a contemporary English copy. He describes his process of rewriting and publishing the text in 1954, asserting its unique existence and value to occultists. He briefly touches on the former owner's defrocking due to his magical experiments.

This section details the rigorous preliminary steps for ceremonial magic, including a seven-day period of solitude, fasting (bread and water), prayer, and purification. It outlines the drawing of a 9-foot diameter magic circle and the meticulous consecration of essential ritual items: pentacles, vestments, altar, candles, girdle, holy water, the ritual sword, lamens (circles), and specific perfumes.

The grimoire provides specific daily invocations tailored to the seven classical planets (Sun, Moon, Mars, Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, Saturn). Each invocation is accompanied by a unique symbolic diagram or 'seal' (e.g., a heptagram for Sunday/Sun, a pentagram for Monday/Moon), incorporating Hebrew divine names and angelic appeals to align the operation with the planetary influences.

This part features the unique 'characters' (sigils) for the seven Olympian Planetary Lords: Aratron (Saturn), Phaleg (Mars), Phul (Moon), Bethor (Jupiter), Ophiel (Mercury), Hagith (Venus), and Och (Sun). For each lord, a specific perfume recipe is provided, utilizing various herbs, woods, animal products, and minerals, intended to create the appropriate atmospheric conditions for their invocation.

Instructions for donning vestments with specific orations are given, followed by a general prayer for purification, protection, divine grace, and the attainment of wisdom through ministering spirits. This prayer invokes a vast array of holy names and references Christian theological concepts (Nativity, Baptism, Passion, Ascension, Holy Ghost) to empower the magician and command spirits.

The text lists various Spirits, Messengers, and Intelligences associated with each of the seven planets, serving as a directory for direct communication. A detailed invocation specifically for Jupiterian spirits (Sachiel, Castiel, Asasiel) is provided, requesting the sending of messengers (Tarjel, Coniel, Babiel) and the appearance of a spirit (Setchiel, Chedustaniel, Corael) in a benign angelic form to fulfill requests.

This section outlines the ritual dialogue for questioning the summoned spirit (exemplified by 'Turiel') to confirm its identity and purpose. It then details the process of eliciting a binding oath from the spirit, ensuring its future cooperation and the confirmation of its unique 'character' (sigil). The ritual concludes with a 'Licence to Depart,' granting the spirit permission to return to its sphere until called again.

key_concepts.definition: A highly structured form of magic involving elaborate rituals, specific tools, purifications, and the invocation of divine names and spirits for defined purposes.
A magical system that aligns operations with the astrological influences and corresponding spirits of the seven classical planets, utilizing specific days, hours, and ritual components.
A historical lineage of magical textbooks containing instructions for spirit evocation, often featuring seals, invocations, and methods for gaining supernatural assistance or knowledge.
The ritual act of purifying and imbuing oneself and magical tools with divine virtue and power, rendering them sacred and fit for magical work.
Numerous names of God (e.g., Tetragrammaton, Adonay, Elohim, Sabaoth, Agla) used as words of power to establish authority and compel spirits within the ritual context.
A unique symbolic mark or seal representing a specific spirit or planetary lord, used for identification, invocation, and binding purposes in magical operations.

Specific incense mixtures, compounded according to planetary correspondences and utilizing various ingredients, used to create an appropriate energetic and olfactory environment for spirit manifestation.
A specific messenger spirit associated with the sphere of Jupiter, presented as a key entity to be invoked within this grimoire's system for gaining knowledge and assistance.

practical_system.description: The grimoire outlines a comprehensive and demanding system for establishing contact with and commanding planetary spirits, with a particular focus on gaining wisdom and assistance. The system integrates intense personal purification (fasting, prayer, solitude) with meticulous ritual preparations, including the creation and consecration of specific magical tools and the use of planetary-aligned invocations and perfumes. The core operative goal is to summon a spirit (e.g., Turiel), engage in dialogue, extract an oath of service, and obtain its unique sigil for future command.
tools: Incense/Perfumes (specific recipes for each planetary lord)
Crucifix (mentioned in acquisition narrative, but not explicitly as a ritual tool in the operative sections)
rituals: Seven-day pre-ritual purification (solitude, fasting, prayer from sunset to sunrise).
Consecration of Pentacles, Vestments, Altar, Candles, Girdle, Light, Sword, Lamens, Perfumes using specific prayers and divine names.
Daily invocations aligned with the planetary ruler of the day, utilizing specific seals.
Conjuration of spirits through an extensive list of divine names and angelic appeals.
Dialogue with the summoned spirit, including interrogation and confirmation of identity.
Obtaining a binding oath from the spirit for future assistance.
Formal Licence to Depart for the spirit.

relevant_quotes.text: THE SECRET GRIMOIRE OF TURIEL A SYSTEM OF CEREMONIAL MAGIC THE GREAT ARCANUM (The Rites of Ceremonial Magick).

Since 1927 I have rewritten the manuscript owing to the fact that I was on the move so often, and for the sake of convenience the new writing was entered into a note book of convenient size, and the copy purchased in Las Palmas I destroyed. I have reason to believe that the present manuscript is the only one in existence.
OBSERVATIONS and method of Invoking related with great pains and diligent research.

Retire thyself Seven Days free from all company and fast and pray from sunset to sunrise. Rise every morning at Seven of the clock, and the three days previous to the Work fast upon bread and water and humble thyself before Almighty God. Watch and pray all night before the Work.

I implore Thee, O Holy Adonay, Amay, Horta, Vegadoro, Ysion, Ysesy, and by al! Thy Holy Names, and by al! Thine Angels, Archangels, and Powers, Dominations, and Virtues, and by Thy Name with which King Solomon did bind up the devils and shut them np, Ethrack, Evanher, Agla, Goth, Joth, Othie, Venock, Nabrat, and by al! Thy Holy Names which are written in this book, and by the virtue of them all, that Thou enable me to congregate all Thy spirits, that they may give me true answers to all my demands.

I, Turiel, Messenger of the Spirits of Jupiter, appointed there-unto by the Creator of all things visible and invisible, do swear and promise, and plighting faith and troth unto thee in the presence, by, and before the Great Lord of Heaven and the whole company of Heaven, by all the Holy Names of God, do swear and bind myself unto thee... that I will hasten unto thee, and appear clearly unto thee at all times and places, and in all hours, days, and minutes, from this time forward until thy life's end, wbensoever thou shalt call me by my name, or by my Office, and will come unto thee in what form thou shalt desire, whether it be visibly or invisibly; I will answer a!! thy desires.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Secret Grimoire of Turiel stands as a notable example within the modern grimoire tradition, demonstrating a clear continuity with historical ceremonial magic texts. Its detailed instructions for planetary invocation, specific spirit hierarchies, and emphasis on preparatory purification rituals offer a structured pathway for practitioners. The grimoire's unique claim of being a rewritten and singular manuscript from a 16th-century Latin original, re-presented in the mid-20th century, makes it a curious artifact for historical and textual analysis within esotericism. It shows how traditional models of spirit interaction, particularly those seeking wisdom and assistance from specific planetary intelligences, are re-interpreted and re-affirmed.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of advanced students and practitioners of Western Esotericism, particularly those specializing in ceremonial magic, grimoire traditions, and planetary magic. It is suitable for occultists who possess a foundational understanding of ritual structure, an ability to engage with lengthy prayers and divine names, and a willingness to undertake rigorous physical and spiritual preparations. Researchers of occult history and practitioners seeking a direct, operative system of spirit communication would also find this text highly relevant.
